warningGhgNotMet:
Your selection of measures did not meet the European greenhouse gas reduction target. This has several severely negative implications:
  • Belgium will have to pay other European member states € {{ tax }}. By selecting more measures, Belgium might receive additional funding instead.
  • If Belgium doesn't reduce its greenhouse gas emissions sufficiently, this means that other European member states will have to compensate - and they may be in a much more difficult position to do so. We can only meet the goals if everyone does his part.

helpDialogCarbonTax:
When a European member state does not meet its CO2 reduction target, yearly, it must pay a tax equal to the amount of emissions it is below the target reduction requirement. The price of these missed reductions is determined by the ETS system; and cannot be determined beforehand. A realistic assumption is € 100 per ton of CO2. 

This would explain everythig in more detail, and link to estimations of the average emissions price.
helpDialogCarbonIncome:
When a European member state emits less than its target, it can sell its excess emission rights to Europe. A realistic price assumption is € 100 per ton of CO2.

This would explain everything in more detail, and link to estimations of the average emissions price.

worst-consequences.text:
Either way, the world will look different with a 1.5° or 2°C rise. But the higher the temperature rise, the greater the risks. At a temperature of 2°, some parts of the planet already become uninhabitable for humans, which would cause mass migration.

The higher the temperature, the greater the likelihood of self-enforcing effects, which could cause even more warming.

For an overview of the difference between 1.5°, 2° and 3° C, see this interactive page from Climate Brief.

rich-countries-more-than-others.text:
Since the start of the industrial revolution in the nineteenth century, industrial countries have emitted a lot of CO2, burning coal and later oil and gas to generate energy. This abundant energy has made us so rich today, but unfortunately its effects remain for centuries, in the form of greenhouse gases.

Over the centuries, Europe, for example, emitted 542 billion tonnes of CO2. Although China today emits far more than Europe, throughout history it has only emitted about half as much, 260 billion tonnes. Africa only 51 billion tonnes -- and that includes emissions from the colonial period.

Richer countries also have more opportunities to reduce their emissions. Especially when we look at emissions per person, and emissions from our consumption. Belgium is among the world leaders in this regard with 17.2 tonnes per year per person. A Chinese person consumes an average of 7.2 tonnes per year, an Indian 1.7 tonnes, an average African 1 tonne.

Given all this, can we ask them to reduce their emissions even more?

european-targets.text:
The fight against climate change must be fought at the highest possible level, to create as level a playing field as possible between countries. The highest possible level for us is Europe.

Europe adopted a "climate law" in 2023 to be climate neutral by 2050. It also set reduction targets along the way. With 'Fit for 55', Europe's ambition is to reduce its emissions by 55% from 1990 levels by 2030. In February 2024, Europe decided to aim for a 90% reduction by 2040. That is the minimum that is needed to achieve neutrality by 2050.

To get there, roughly two complementary systems are operating in Europe. European power generation and heavy industry are covered by the Emission Trading System (ETS), a cap-and-trade system in which total emissions are determined, fall annually, and countries that emit more must buy allowances from countries that emit less. From 2027, road transport and building heating will also be covered by this system.

For the remaining sectors (buildings and road transport until 2027, small industry, agriculture and waste treatment), member states are responsible themselves. The effor is shared among member states (hence Effort Sharing Regulation or ESR), and national governments must monitor this themselves through national legislation. Belgium must, for these sectors, reduce its emissions by 47% by 2030 compared to 2005.

2.title: Starting 2026

3.title: Starting 2024

obligatory-display-of-carbon-footprint-o.title: Obligatory display of carbon footprint on products and services
obligatory-display-of-carbon-footprint-o.summary: The federal government requires all suppliers of products and services to display the carbon footprint (and optionally wider ecological impact), so consumers can take that into account.

1.title: Starting 2025, limited
1.summary: In this scenario, warehouses are only required to start applying the eco-score starting in 2025, the footprint is only limited to CO2-emissions, and only food and consumable products have to be labeled.

2.title: Starting 2024, limited, eco-score
2.summary: In this more ambitious scenario, warehouses are required to start applying the eco-score starting in 2024, the footprint not only limited to CO2-emissions but also a couple of other ecological impacts such as potential biodiversity loss. Only food and consumable products must be labeled.

3.title: Starting 2024, complete, eco-score
3.summary: In this scenario, warehouses are required to start applying the eco-score starting in 2023, the footprint not only limited to CO2-emissions but also its exhaustive ecological and social impact. All products must be labeled (albeit with different starting dates as feasible for the sector).

dri-installation-arcelor.title: DRI installation Arcelor
dri-installation-arcelor.summary: ArcelorMittal Belgium will reduce CO2 emissions by 3.9 million tonnes per year by 2030, by building a 2.5 million-tonne direct reduced iron (DRI) plant and two electric furnaces at its Gent site, to operate alongside its state-of-the-art blast furnace that is ready to take waste wood and plastics as a substitute for fossil carbon.

ccs-projects.title: CCS projects
ccs-projects.summary: Carbon capture & storage projects at BASF, Air Liquide, and in the future other companies.

reduction-cattle-pig-herds.title: Reduction of cattle and pig herds
reduction-cattle-pig-herds.summary: Reduction in cattle and pig herds by 2030 compared to 2021. For the pig herd, the current rate of reduction should accelerate slightly, for beef cattle the rate should triple, and for dairy cattle the upward trend should be completely reversed. Flanders would have about 400,000 fewer cattle by 2030. Intervention in the poultry population has little effect.
